results.description:
Ride the 2015 Tour de Bronx!

The Bronx is NOT burning!! Join nearly 6,000 cyclists as they hit the road for the Tour de Bronx, the largest free cycling event in New York State.

With a choice of either a 25 or 40-mile course through the borough’s 61 neighborhoods, there will be fun for casual riders and avid bicyclists. Every year local, national and even international visitors make their way to the Bronx just to be a part of the “Big Bronx Ride!”

Presented by the Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz, Jr. and Transportation Alternatives and produced by the Bronx Tourism Council, the Tour de Bronx promotes bicycling and pedestrian environmentally-friendly methods of travel.

*All Riders must check-in on the morning of the tour prior to the 9 a.m. start time.*


Routes: (a) The 40 mile


This quicker-paced ride ventures farther afield to visit iconic Bronx sites like City Island, Woodlawn Cemetery and SUNY Maritime College. This ride is recommended for experienced cyclists comfortable riding in traffic . THERE IS NO SAFETY CELL ON THIS RIDE. Kids under 16 must be accompanied by a parent or guardian.

(b) The 25 mile

A leisurely ride that's great for every age and skill level. Enjoy Bronx Greenway bike paths, park lands, shoreline and more. Riders will be accompanied by marshals and NYPD escorts.


Getting There:

The 2015 tour starts at the Bronx County Building at Grand Concourse & 161st Street and ends with a music festival at the New York Botanical Garden!

+


Register HERE for the bike ride!!

**PLEASE NOTE: You must register for either the 25- or 40-mile bike ride at the above link in order to be admitted to this event. Please do not RSVP to this event without registering!


+


Afterwards:

There's a music festival at the NY Botanical Gardens (our end point) and recommendation to go to the Bronx Beer Hall. We'll check out the festival but will likely grab a  beer at the Bronx Brewery, 5.3 miles south of the Botanical Garden at 856 E 136th St, Bronx, NY 10454. Stay tuned.
results.how_to_find_us: Text Mike when you arrive, 203.586.8036
results.name: 2015 Tour de Bronx (25 or 40-mile bike ride)

results.description:
Did you forget to sing? Perhaps after Third Grade, when the peer pressure set in. Perhaps someone picked out the "Gifted and Talented" - and it wasn't you. Or maybe the Nuns made you sing "God Bless America" and someone laughed. Or you were one of the "Blue Birds" - you moved your mouth but didn't make any sound. Or did you sing beautifully in that Elementary School play? Was it the Middle School chorus, where the boys were thrown out and it ended up a Girls Club that made a sound in three parts, so beautiful nothing to this day has extinguished that feeling? Perhaps you were one of the guys who made harmony in the reverb of the Boys Room, or in the audience at the concert, or the sports stadium, or in the shower?

Or maybe you played an instrument that kept your mouth busy, and you never did get the chance to sing? Was it the race of competition for excellence in something, something else, that left you no time?

Was is the implicit warning, between the lines of the praises of privilege, that you should not express yourself? Did you forget that feeling of camaraderie and being a part of something bigger than yourself? Did you forget that amazement you felt at yourself being able to memorize a large piece and give it your all - weeks and months of practice that lead to a performance, or several, that made you feel powerful, hopeful, inspired and you had drawn upon that experience to guide your life? You had that moment, lifted by the magic of the "ordered progression though time and space," that made life so rich, so romantic, so filled with spirit.

And then did you forget?

Forget that feeling, that high, that experience of joy and sadness, playing the part, being a messenger, a vessel. You forgot that there are scientific studies praising the participation in music and art, the health benefits, the raised white blood cell count, the relaxation response, the breathing, the healing power of sound, or just the old saying, "singing is good for you."

Now you have another chance.

Don't miss it.
results.name: Did You Forget to Sing?

results.description:
Earlier classes on Parable of Jesus and on "Our Father" prayer were excellent, whether you are Christian or not, a believer or not (Scott's comment).

Unitarian Universalists are rightfully proud of a tradition that remains open to the spiritual insights of many different religious traditions. Frequently, however, this openness masks a reluctance to explore the very traditions out of which we ourselves have emerged. In this series Rev. Robb will take a fresh look at the spiritual insightfulness and moral imagination contained in the teaching of Jesus while emphasizing how they may continue to be revelatory in our current context. It is always surprising to look carefully at the actual words of great teachers with whom we have assumed we were fairly familiar and to discover new ways of understanding and fresh insights of which we were unaware. In this series we will examine in depth some of the stories Jesus told—the parables—which were probably the most characteristic and innovative way he had to convey his own spiritual vision.


 Rev. David Robb

is Assistant Minister for Adult Education and Scholar-In-Residence at All Souls. He is also a psychotherapist and pastoral counselor in practice in New York City and an Associate of Kenwood Psychological Services. He formerly taught Theology at Georgetown University and Religious Studies at Connecticut College.

results.description:
The Harlem Valley Rail Trail provides a scenic ride through rolling farm fields and dense woods on the bed of the New York and Harlem Railroad that ran from New York City to Chatham, New York. The rail-trail has been built in segments, and there is still work to be done to open all 46 miles of the paved road trail. Virginia has volunteered to guide those doing a shorter 25 miles total also.

The southern end of the trail begins at the Metro North Railroad Station in Wassaic, New York. It is possible, during non-rush hours and on weekends, to board a Metro North train in Grand Central Station and in a little more than two hours be peddling or walking along this rail-trail. As the trail points north for nearly 11 miles to Millerton, it passes through a pastoral scene. Farmland stretches before and around you, followed by red-cedar scrubland and beaver ponds. In Amenia, the trailhead parking lot is on the site of the former Barton House, a large hotel.


Several railroad stations on this line have been restored: Sharon Station is now a private residence located off the trail in the town of North East. Millerton's three stations have been restored and today house local businesses. North of Coleman Station the trail crosses six reconstructed railroad bridges.

The railroad builders tamed the area's rolling terrain, and created a level corridor, by blasting through rock and building the rail bed up from the land adjacent to the corridor for a "pyramiding" effect. In several stretches, north of Route 61, the trail's higher elevation on steep embankments , in some places dropping 50 feet—provides spectacular views of the surrounding farmland. Indian Mountain, straddling the border of New York and Connecticut, is to the east. Traveling through a series of deep rock cuts, you will feel the temperature drop several degrees from the surrounding landscape.

The next 8 miles of the railroad corridor between Main Street in Millerton and Under Mountain Road in Ancram are not open for public use.

Reaching the next open trail section requires a detour on a two-lane road. Head west on Main Street in Millerton and then north on New York State Route 22 for about 7.7 miles. Turn right on Under Mountain Road and look for the trailhead on the left. The 4-mile paved section of trail between Under Mountain Road and Taconic State Park is more wooded where the trail hugs the base of the South Taconic Mountains.

About 2.9 miles north of Under Mountain Road, the trail detours onto a scenic dirt road for 0.4 mile to bypass a privately held parcel of rail bed. The dirt road rejoins the paved rail-trail for another 0.5 mile to the entrance to Taconic State Park at Copake Falls. Scenic Bash Bish Falls is located about 1 mile east of the trailhead, just over the Massachusetts state border. Follow the hiking trail to reach the falls.
Edit Description Parking and Trail Access

To reach the Wassaic trailhead: From I-84 or I-684, take State Route 22 north at Brewster. Continue north on Route 22 to the Wassaic Station of the Metro North Railroad. The station is on the right side of the road.

To reach the Taconic State Park Trailhead: From I-84 or I-684, take State Route 22 north to Brewster. Continue north on Route 22 to State Route 344, about 6 miles north of Millerton. Turn right and proceed about 0.5 mile to the triangular green. Bear to the left to the stop sign. Proceed straight about 0.3 mile to the entrance of Taconic State Park; ask the attendant where to park.

Bring:  Water, Helmet, Snacks for energy, cell phone, Road bike, (although I had many one gear and mtn bikers come too.)

LUNCH:  We will be stopping for lunch.

Carpool or taking the train.:  Please indicate which you need.
results.name: Autum Harlem Valley Rail trail-

Fall is here! Lets go hiking! 


Parking: N[masked] W[masked]
Rt 287 to exit 55, take 511 N (Wanaque), continue through Wanaque for several miles. Make a left onto West Brook Rd. Continue across Reservoir. At the T-intersection, make a left. The 2nd left is Snake Den Road. There is a sign for the Weis Ecology and the Highlands Natural Pool on the left side of the road. Continue uphill and bear left on Snake Den, continue past some houses until arriving at a large dirt lot on the right.
Also, please, indicate if you are looking for a ride or have space in the car.

http://www.njhiking.com/best-hikes-in-nj-norvin-green/

Quoting Alex Chernov below: 

DO NOT BE LATE.

Please, be on time. We WILL NOT wait for late comers. If you come late, go and play with bears. In the woods. Alone. 

BRING COMFORTABLE SHOES.

What can I say? Ladies on high heels, I like you, but no on the day of the hike. Bring good pair of sneakers or better hiking boots. 

BRING FOOD AND WATER 

This hike could take longer than you expect. You WILL get hungry and thirsty. And, yes, I will be selling water for $20 dollars a bottle. Just ask. Also, all kinds of stupid trail mixes and candy bars are not food. At least not for me. So, get yourself nice sandwich and a couple of water bottles. And guess what, this also means that you will need a backpack. 

POST-HIKING ACTIVITY

TBD

Disclaimer: You are hiking at your own risk!
results.name: Fall Hike

On October 25th, we'll be staging two special events at Columbia University. We're reaching out because you represent a small group of Sherlock collaborators that have come in and out of the project over the last 12 months. We wanted to extend the invitation to you first to see if you'd be interested in joining us. 


Sunday, October 25th  


10am to 6pm 

Come design, play and make with participants around the world. We're partnering with IoT NYC (a meetup community with over 2,800 members) and folks from the Columbia Engineering School to run a story + maker session. We'll be prototyping and tinkering with story & code. This will be a great mix of storytellers, game designers, makers and hackers.

Location

Columbia University  

Room 601 Fairchild Hall - Morningside Campus   116th Broadway entrance

Open Resource

results.description:
Sustainable Flatbush and Sacred Vibes Apothecary continue their successful series of FREE community workshops on the use of herbs for health and wellness.

Q Gardens will host two great workshops on Sunday, October 25, 2015.

10:30am – 1pm
EXPRESS YO'SELF!
Strengthen Your Voice & Being with Plant Medicine
with Anyanwu and Emerson.

Release better, breathe better, feel better. This workshop is for anyone that wants to stand in their power and understand how the use of your voice can change you life. We will cover communication as it relates to the throat chakra and how the use of your voice impacts organ health and social/emotional well-being. Through learning about medicinal plants that support the respiratory system, digestion, and thyroid glands, we will explore the ways these plants can support us in speaking our truth. Come and learn about the following herbs that are connected to strengthening your ability to 'EXPRESS YO'SELF!':
• Dandelion - digestive system and liver support
• Mullein – lung and nervous system support
• Lemon Balm – nervous system and thyroid function support
• Tulsi – digestive system support

1:30 – 3pm
Creating Womb Care Rituals
with Natalie.

In this workshop participants will learn about herbs which promote a healthy and balanced reproductive system. We will explore different ways to prepare delicious elixirs and healing steam baths.
_____________________________________________________

To RSVP, or for more information, please email Kate at: kate.florence @gmail.com.

Materials: In many of our workshops we spend time making different herbal preparations such as teas, tinctures, oils, and syrups. If you would like to bring some home with you, please bring a clean 2 oz. baby food jar. If you have more than 1 jar, bring some to share!

Accessibility: It is important to us that our workshops are as accessible as possible. Our outdoor workshops are held in a space with no steps or stairs, however not all walkways are paved. Please contact Kate, if you have any accessibility concerns or needs.

See you in the garden!!!
results.name: Sustainable Flatbush & Sacred Vibes Host a Day of Healing @ Q Gardens

results.description:
COME JOIN US FOR A 15-20 MILE MOUNTAIN BIKE RIDE AT MINNEWASKA STATE PARK.

WE WILL START AT THE PETERS KILL PARKING AREA OFF TO THE RIGHT ABOUT 1/2 MILE BEFORE THE MAIN ENTRANCE GATE TO MINNEWASKA.

Our route will cover both Lake Awosting and Lake Minnewaska and will include the Awosting Falls Carriage Road, Lower Awosting Carriage Road, Lake Awosting Carriage Road, Upper Awosting Carriage Road, Millbrook Mountain Carriage Road and Hamilton Point Carriage Road.

Please Note: the Castle Point Carriage Road is closed for restoration and will not be part of our route this trip.

Located in Ulster County, NY Minnewaska State Park Preserve is situated on the dramatic Shawangunk Mountain ridge, which rises more than 2,000 feet above sea level and is surrounded by rugged, rocky terrain. The park features numerous waterfalls, three crystalline sky lakes, dense hardwood forests, incising sheer cliffs and ledges opening to beautiful views, clear streams cut into valleys and 35 miles of carriageways on which to bike and simply enjoy.

For more info on the park please visit: http://nysparks.com/parks/127/details.aspx

Distance: Approximately 15-20 miles

Estimated Bike Time: 4-5 hours

Difficulty:  Intermediate - A good deal of hill climbing on Carriage Roads with Gravel

Current Weather Forecast: Partly Sunny with a high of 59 degrees

Fee:  Please Note there is an $10. fee to park per carload if you don't have an Empire Passport

MANDATORY GEAR:

• Mountain Bike or Hybrid

• Bicycle Helmet

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Clear eye Protection (safety glasses - for bugs, dirt, etc.)

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, Sunscreen, bug spray, etc.

• Bike Pump

• Tire Patch Kit and/or Spare Tube

• Warm Layers, Windbreaker, Gloves


PLEASE INSPECT YOUR BIKE PRIOR TO ARRIVAL TO INSURE THE FOLLOWING:

• Proper Tire Inflation

• Lubricated chain

• Properly Shifting gears

• Functional Brakes that don't rub rim or tire when released.

RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set

(Specifically Trail Map 104)


BIKE RENTALS ARE AVAILABLE FROM:

http://www.bicycledepot.com/rentals
Contact and Hours

15 Main Street
New Paltz, NY 12561
(845)[masked]

[masked]
www.bicycledepot.com

Sunday: 10am-5pm


AFTER THE HIKE FEEL FREE TO JOIN US FOR FOOD AND DRINKS AT THE EGG'S NEST RESTAURANT (CASH ONLY - ATM ON SITE) **Venue subject to change based on group interest**

1300 State Rte 213

High Falls, New York

Open 11:30 AM ~ Serving Lunch & Dinner Daily

http://theeggsnest.com/

The Eggs Nest, located in High Falls, NY also fondly known as the “Center of the Universe”, is an Ulster County institution. It is owned and operated by the all around artist Richard Murphy who describes the Eggs Nest as “a living canvas.”  For 40 years it has and continues to be a focal point for the community–a place where good friends meet, be it old-time friends or those we just haven’t met yet. Let our friendly staff meet you at the door and welcome you into our restaurant, a feast for the eyes and a feast for the belly. Enjoy our reasonably priced eclectic menu which features southwestern dishes as well as hamburgers, deli sandwiches, soups and quiche du jour, and a wide selection of Eggs Nest specialties, delights, vegetarian dishes, and nightly specials. Top off your meal with an ample dessert from the menu that features something for everyone. Our hope is that you will be totally satisfied and become part of the Eggs Nest family returning again and again.

results.description:
As the fall foliage starts to peak, let's tour Riverdale Park (secluded woods overlooking the Hudson and Palisades); Wave Hill (lawns, gardens, greenhouses, art gallery, gift shop, and great Hudson River vistas); the amazing mansions of Fieldston, an exclusive private community that we have special permission to visit; and the pristine forests of huge Van Cortland Park. Please read the details and instructions below, to ensure that you're properly prepared.


DISTANCE: Six miles (less if you leave early, of course), with some fairly gentle ups and downs.


PACE: MODERATE (2.5 MPH), NOT SLOW. PLEASE, IF YOU WANT TO WALK SLOWLY, THIS IS NOT THE RIGHT EVENT FOR YOU. 


ENDING TIME: About5 PM. You can leave earlier, of course. But once we enter the woods, at around 3 PM, there's no turning back.

LUNCH: BRING YOUR OWN--NO EXCEPTIONS. We'll eat at about 2 PM, so have a big breakfast or pack a snack in addition to lunch, to tide you over. And dress warmly enough to sit outside for about half an hour.

COST: $8 for Wave Hill ($4 students and seniors); $4.25 one way for Metro North (buy a "city ticket" before boarding); and $2 for me, in part to cover meetup's organizer fee. 

TRANSPORTATION: 10:20 Metro North train from Grand Central to Riverdale, arriving 10:48. (Buy a $4.25 "City Ticket.") Return by either the #1 subway train or Metro North.


Drivers: See street address of train station (with parking lot). If your GPS doesn't accept Railroad Terrace, try Palisades Avenue instead, and drive one more block toward the river on W. 254th St. Either way, turn right at the end of 254th just before the yacht club entrance; that will bring you to the parking lot next to the train platform.

Drivers and those returning by Metro North rather than bus and subway will need to walk back to the station on their own--a moderately uphill, one-mile walk from Van Cortland (or half a mile from Wave Hill), using a map that I'll provide. Alternatively, Metro North riders could take the subway, without that walk, to the nearby Marble Hill Metro North station.

WAITING LIST: Sign up and be patient, no matter how many are waiting. The waiting list will shrink because of cancellations, especially at the last minute. And you can come if you're in the top 20 on the list (shown below the main list on the right side of this page on a computer--not an app or mobile device) at any time before the walk starts. As a courtesy to others waiting for a spot, please do not sign up unless you intend to go, rather than just as a placeholder in case nothing better turns up.

results.description:
This workshop examines the common myths and truths about pregnancy nutrition.

When it comes to pregnancy nutrition, understanding which key nutrients are most important can help you make good choices for you and your developing baby. Here are some examples of the myths we will cover that moms-to-be often hear about nutrition and the truth behind the real advice:

• MYTH: Your baby will rely on the nutrient reserves in your body and get everything he needs, regardless of what you eat. 

• MYTH: If you didn’t eat balanced meals before becoming pregnant, it’s too late. 

• MYTH: Fish is not safe to eat during your pregnancy. 

• MYTH: Any food in moderation is fine during pregnancy. 


Come for a bit of brunch, interactive learning and mom-to-mom bonding and support =)

Please RSVP and contact Eva for any further questions.
results.how_to_find_us: Text Eva at 914-380-2003 to get the exact location
results.name: Pregnancy Nutrition Myths Debunked: What does "Healthy"­ really mean?

results.description:
http://www.nysec.org/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/images/IHEU.jpg?itok=Os6mIRsf International Humanist & Ethical Union Executive Committee

Dr. Anne Klaeysen, Leader presides  

Andrew Copson:: Rein Zunderdorp:: Roar Johnsen:: Ane-France Ketelaer:: Susan Sackett:: Ron Solomon:: Carl Blackburn:: Bob Churchill 

Founded in Amsterdam in 1952, the IHEU vision is a Humanist world; a world in which human rights are respected and everyone is able to live a life of dignity. IHEU works to build and represent the global Humanist movement that defends human rights and promotes Humanist values world-wide. Headquartered in London, IHEU is an international non-governmental organization with representation on various United Nations committees and other international bodies. We seek to influence international policy through representation and information, to build the humanist network, and let the world know about the worldview of Humanism.  The 6 members of the IHEU Executive Committee and one or two staff members will elaborate on the activities of IHEU and how humanism and humanist issues manifest themselves in our various countries and elsewhere in the world.

Entry to our 100-year-old building and meeting rooms is available for most wheelchair users with prior arrangements. Please call ahead  [masked] x 107) for setup of our portable system and plan to arrive one hour before start time.

Okay...so this is going to be awesome. We did it in June and it was awesome.

So we're doing it again! 16 players, one tournament.

The format is going to be LEGACY. This time.

We'll play three rounds of swiss and then cut to top 8 for quarter finals, semis and finals. So max of Six matches if you make it all the way.

And as usual...proxies are welcome and encouraged. If you don't have a deck...make one! 60 card constructed, plus 15 card sideboards.

We're going to ask for a $10 entry fee...with the cash money going to the top four finishers. The split will be 80/$40/$20/$20 for top four. All matches will be best of 3 games.

Our good friend Kenny Bross is graciously hosting us at his office, located in Midtown...see location for address.

If you have questions about any of this, feel free to message me on here or text 6464273362.

We're going to meet at 11:00 AM and start the rounds at 12:00 PM. Hopefully everyone arrives in a timely fashion.

Please RSVP as soon as possible so we can get to a solid 16. This should be a lot of fun.

results.description:
The fundamental way of enriching life with enlightenment is by being complete with all the patterns carried within. Any action that remains unfulfilled as per our fantasy, either due to hindrance from the outside world or from within can be termed as an incompletion. This can be either with ourselves or with another person. If we want a friend to live up to certain expectations that he or she can not honour, then it leads to incompletion. The first step to healing such an incompletion is to render the relationship complete. The only way to do this is by facing the other person and healing the hurt caused in the relationship. This can also be done by invoking their presence if they are no longer physically present. This process of completion and subsequent healing is absolutely necessary. Unless we are complete in all dimensions, life does not begin – living does not happen in us.

Similarly, incompletion also happens internally. Any unfulfilled desire or fantasy carried by us, relating to ourselves, remains as an incompletion. The ideas which we have about us, we should either fulfill them or drop them. If we can not afford to fulfill them with our adopted lifestyle then dropping those will bring about completion with ourselves. For completion to happen, authentic listening needs to happen first. We need to authentically listen to the cries of our heart. This does not mean we will do everything that our heart wants. Just listening to our heart can give tremendous self satisfaction. Completion with ourselves involves giving ourselves the much needed self-attention. It even cures physical pain, as pain is a simple manifestation of being unable to sit comfortably with oneself.

When there is a disturbance, the source is invariably from within us. Be it any kind of hindrance, this technique of completion within the self will be the path to enriching one’s life and cleansing the body of all negativity in its varied forms.


by Nithyananda Times on May 29, 2013 in Completion, Meditation
Be Complete!
results.name: Are you incomplete with you?  Learn a meditation for inner peace & fulfillment.

group.name: Find Bliss Now! - Meditators of Port Washington

results.description:
You can experience the colors of fall's foliage from the water. We will head out to North West NJ for some kayaking time at the Monksville Reservoir. The lake is in Long Pond Ironworks State Park, and is known for its old stone walls, furnaces and other remnants of a once industrious ironworking community that now sits next to the swiftly flowing Wanaque River. Being a flat water lake this tour is perfect for the beginner. Want a nice long paddle, visit the 505-acre Monksville Reservoir that encircles Long Pond Ironworks State Park like a giant horseshoe. You’ll find the most interesting paddling on the far side of the reservoir, where coves of all sizes form a continuous string along the highly irregular shoreline. White birches seem particularly abundant around the lake, contrasting sharply against dark evergreens. Ducks and geese can be found around the lake in the protected

Synthetic clothing is the best choice for kayaking. Please do not wear cotton clothing. When wet, cotton rapidly robs the heat from your body and takes a long time to dry. Dress in multiple layers, allowing you more flexibility to comfortably respond to the weather conditions and your level of exertion.

NOTICE: By attending an event you are agreeing that YOU ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR YOUR OWN SAFETY AT ALL TIMES. No member of the group EXCEPT YOURSELF can be held responsible for any damages, accidents, or liabilities incurred while paddling with us. Paddling is an inherently dangerous sport. Information is provided with the understanding that the providers are not engaged in rendering advice on technical matters, equipment performance, safety, or any other aspect of the sport in absolute terms or advocating any of the techniques or experiences described.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be on the south side look for Silver HHR with two kayaks
results.name: Kayak in Monksville Reservoir to view fall foliage

results.description:
It's time for Bronies-NYC's next and much anticipated Nerf War!

The leaves are falling and the darts will be flying this month as we meet on the lower east side for another epic throwdown.

If you are interested in participating, be sure to give the information below a quick glance!

Do I need to bring my own Nerf Blaster?

Absolutely not, though you're welcome to if you'd like to ensure you get to use what you want. There will be plenty of Nerf Blasters to go around of all shapes and sizes.

Is there a cost to participate?

No! This meetup is totally free. We do ask that you bring some small number of standard Nerf Darts (see below) to cover yourself and any guests attending for you. This is not mandatory, nor should you feel obliged to bring a large quantity of darts, but it's always better to have more than enough than not enough at all. Please note that you are more than likely to leave with fewer darts than you brought with you as darts will become lost and damaged in the event!

What Shouldn't I Bring?

Nerf Blasters, Swords, Axes, and similar knock-off products are all OK - hard plastic/wood/metal weapons (other than blasters, of course) and anything sharp is strictly forbidden! If you choose to bring any sort of Nerf Gun which uses non-standard Darts (Mega Darts, Rockets, Disks, etc.) you will be responsible for your own ammunition for the entirety of the event (handling recovery, etc.) so keep this in mind.

What Should I Wear?

It's getting cool out, so dress warm with the option to remove outer layers of clothing (jacket/sweater) in case it's hotter than expected. If you plan to represent a specific team, bring a bandana/colored band/clothing indicative of which team you plan to support. Feel free to bring clothing for either side if you're unsure which team you'll be playing on.

Is there a Code of Conduct?

Strictly speaking, no, however you should keep in mind that this is a public space. We are subject to the whim of the park rangers (last time they let us stay) so be on your best behavior - we certainly don't want to hear any complaints of be kicked out of the park. Likewise, unnecessary roughhousing is not permitted and any and all attendees should always be listening for instructions from the current Ref/Host who will identify themselves at the start of the meetup. In short, if someone in charge is speaking, you should be listening.

What types of Darts should I Bring?

Standard Nerf Darts are called "Steamliners" and can be found at any major retailer/toy store. They're easily identifiable by their rounded rubber tip. Suction Cup Darts, Velcro Darts, Mega Darts, Disks and other non-standard ammunition may not work with all Nerf Blasters. If you're unsure what Darts do and do not work with your Blaster, ASK!

http://vignette2.wikia.nocookie.net/nerf/images/c/cd/123366_S.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20130705221144

Want to know everything about everything regarding different types of darts? Check here!

PLEASE READ

We will be meeting at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Park however depending on the size of our group and the current crowd already at the park we may relocate to the adjacent Teardrop Park (a very short walk away). If demand is high enough, we may very well start our meetup in Teardrop Park. That in mind, show up ON TIME! The later you show up, the later we start, and the later we start the more difficult it will be to work around other guests in the park. Please note that Teardrop Park does close for the winter, I have yet to confirm if it will still be open by this date and will do so shortly.

Questions? Comments? Suggestions?

Post them Below!
results.how_to_find_us: Teardrop Park is closest to the Chambers St (1,2,3/A,C,E) and Park Pl (2,3) stops, just head West towards the water.
results.name: Bronies NYC Nerf War - Fall-time Free-for-All!

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
The Ethical Cultural Society of Bergen County has invited Peggy Wong back to speak of the Palisades Cliffs on Sunday, Oct. 25th, 11 a.m - 12:30 p.m. at 687 Larch Ave., Teaneck, NJ. Talk will cover all the Palisades Cliffs, both north and south of GW Bridge.

http://ethicalfocus.org/event/platform-meeting-2015-10-04-2015-10-25/
results.name: Palisades Cliffs Talk

results.description:
Speaker: Lucy  Schmitz

Details: The National Ethical Service is an affiliated organization with the American Ethical Union (Ethical Culture) and the United Nations. Lucy Schmitz, a youth intern with the National Ethical Service, will discuss her work with the UN, as well as the Movement for a Culture of Peace and the UN's Sustainable Development goals.

About the Speaker: Lucy Schmitz is an undergraduate student at Columbia University studying Political Science and Human Rights. She is a member of the Ethical Culture Society of Essex County in New Jersey. 

For more information: http://www.rysec.org/event/culture-of-peace


Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>;
results.how_to_find_us: Directions on website or call the office during the week.
results.name: Culture of Peace: Talk on the United Nations

venue.name: Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County

results.description:
Peggy Wong will talk about the efforts to preserve and protect the Palisades Cliffs. This is often at odds with developers and local officials who are looking for increased tax ratables. She will also report on the LG settlement and its continuing saga and other breaking news.

Peggy Wong is a lifelong resident of Hudson County and a retired hospitality interior designer of multi-million dollar hotel developments in the U.S. and abroad. As a senior designer, she has worked closely with developers, architects, engineers and other industry professionals. In 2009 she founded and became the president of Coalition to Preserve the Palisades Cliffs Inc.
results.name: Peggy Wong: efforts to preserve and protect the Palisades Cliffs

group.name: The Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County

venue.address_1: West 86th Street and Central Park West
venue.name: Central Park West Quidditch Pitch

results.description:
These are our regular season open practices.

Come and practice with the team! Learn to play quidditch!

Get ready to jump into the fast paced game of quidditch. All experience levels are welcome. The Badassilisks are an inclusive team that seeks to have fun and compete at the highest levels. If you want to join the team, practice with them and speak with one of the coaches!

If you are nervous about playing, we encourage you to still come down. You can watch from the side and talk to players before deciding to play.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter the park at West 86th and immediately make a left. You will see the pitch area.
results.name: Regular Season Practice

results.description:
You can experience the colors of fall's foliage from the water. We will head out to North West NJ for some kayaking time at the Monksville Reservoir. The lake is in Long Pond Ironworks State Park, and is known for its old stone walls, furnaces and other remnants of a once industrious ironworking community that now sits next to the swiftly flowing Wanaque River. Being a flat water lake this tour is perfect for the beginner. Want a nice long paddle, visit the 505-acre Monksville Reservoir that encircles Long Pond Ironworks State Park like a giant horseshoe. You’ll find the most interesting paddling on the far side of the reservoir, where coves of all sizes form a continuous string along the highly irregular shoreline. White birches seem particularly abundant around the lake, contrasting sharply against dark evergreens. Ducks and geese can be found around the lake in the protected

Synthetic clothing is the best choice for kayaking. Please do not wear cotton clothing. When wet, cotton rapidly robs the heat from your body and takes a long time to dry. Dress in multiple layers, allowing you more flexibility to comfortably respond to the weather conditions and your level of exertion.

NOTICE: By attending an event you are agreeing that YOU ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR YOUR OWN SAFETY AT ALL TIMES. No member of the group EXCEPT YOURSELF can be held responsible for any damages, accidents, or liabilities incurred while paddling with us. Paddling is an inherently dangerous sport. Information is provided with the understanding that the providers are not engaged in rendering advice on technical matters, equipment performance, safety, or any other aspect of the sport in absolute terms or advocating any of the techniques or experiences described.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be on the south side look for Silver HHR with two kayaks
results.name: Kayak in Monksville Reservoir to view fall foliage

results.description: Free face painting, free games, live music, free pumpkin decorating, free inflatable slide, craft & specialty vendors.
results.name: New Hope Church Fall Fest

results.description:
Lets meet for a day of pumpkin picking , explore the farmers market for a fresh lunch and taste and enjoy this acclaimed vineyards wines

The Harbes have been farming on Long Island for over 13 generations and over the years have evolved into a North Fork destination where friends can enjoy anything from our fresh picked corn to our award winning wines. In the fall we host the areas finest Fall Festivals featuring pumpkin picking, apple picking, corn mazes, hayrides and much more!

Meet at 11:00 in front of the farm stand .....at 11:15 we'll go pumpkin picking....  Going price I'm told is .55 cents  a lb......go get em..  Car pool meet up at Melville Marriot 1350 Walt Whitman Rd, Melville (Route 110 side of lot ) ....@ 9:45 am and we leave at 10 am Sharp ....  or Meet us at Harbes Mattituck

We'll bring our large gourds to the cars and then lunch and wine tasting....

  Harbes is now my favorite vineyard experience on the north fork.

Tucked away off Sound Avenue is a little barn, beautifully restored on the inside to make for a perfect tasting room.  The wines make the experience even better.  I’ve yet to try a wine on LI that I really liked.  Could tolerate?  Yes.  Was satisfied with? Yes.  But was impressed by?  No…not until Harbes, at least.” – Meghan M.

: Taste any wine – 3 for $10 | 4 for $12 | 5 for $14

Afterwards......consensus rules !  2 Corn Mazes Hayrides, Pony Rides, Gem mining, and much more ....
results.name: Lets go Pumpkin Picking n Wine Tasting Lunch @ Harbes Farm Mattituck

group.name: Hang Out in Queens and Nassau

results.description:
Folks, 
Inviting volunteers to join me at the St Xaviers Church Welcome Kithcen on Sunday to serve over 1000 meals to the poor and homeless provided by St Xaviers Pantry.

This is based on the values that we would treat everyone equal,trustworthy, with dignity without any discrimination. We also want to be socially inclusive, including everyone with their preferences, culture and celebrate diversity. We will serve vegetarian dishes. The Soup Kitchen is dependent on volunteers to help work towards sustaining these values our community. If you are interested in being a volunteer, rsvp through this page. You don't have to be particularly skillful, we believe that if you have the passion, that's all that's needed :)


Soup Kitchen provides the aprons, gloves, hairnets. (one can wear their own baseball hat). Long hair need to be tied back unless it all fit in the hair net. We work with you, show you what to do. Please wear something comfortable.

Type of help could vary from coordinating the line, serving meals, Removing empty plates from the table or general helping out. 

Location -

 Church of St. Francis Xavier (Basement Hall)

46 W. 16th Street (Between 6th and 5th Avenue), New York, NY

Time -

11:30 - 3:30 ( You are required to stay till the end)

I will put my number on the meetup wall once we get close to the date. Members might get different responsibilities but will try to work as a group.
results.name: Vounteer At St Xavier's Church Welcome Kitchen - Feed the Homeless, Good Karma!

The Soup Kitchen is dependent on volunteers to help work towards sustaining these values our community. If you are interested in being a volunteer, rsvp through this page. You don't have to be particularly skillful, we believe that if you have the passion, that's all that's needed :)


Soup Kitchen provides the aprons, gloves, hairnets. (one can wear their own baseball hat). Long hair need to be tied back unless it all fit in the hair net. We work with you, show you what to do. Please wear something comfortable.

Type of help could vary from coordinating the line, serving meals, Removing empty plates from the table or general helping out. 

Location -

 Church of St. Francis Xavier (Basement Hall)

46 W. 16th Street (Between 6th and 5th Avenue), New York, NY

Time -

11:30 - 3:30 ( You are required to stay till the end)

I will put my number on the meetup wall once we get close to the date. Members might get different responsibilities but will try to work as a group.
results.name: Vounteer At St Xavier's Church Welcome Kitchen - Feed the Homeless, Good Karma!

group.name: Mini Adventures For Free - Hiking, Dancing, Sports & More

results.description:
Winner stays, guys!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3XviR7esUvo

And just in case anyone needs a refresher, some guidance from Coach Ted Lasso.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6KeG_i8CWE8

No refunds or credits will be offered. Please be 100% sure that you can attend before you RSVP.

Please have a fun, positive, and supportive attitude. Pass the ball to your teammates and have a good time. NO rough playing, slide tackling, or screaming at others will be tolerated. You'll be removed from the game immediately.

No cleats are allowed. Let's do our part to preserve the field. Turf or running shoes are recommended.

Always bring a *dark and white* t-shirt

Be on time.

Teams are broken out ahead of each game based on skill level. Beginner, intermediate, and advanced players are all encouraged to join.

We play THREE, 25-30 minute games with a brief break between each game.

How to get to Queens West Sportsfield.

Queens West Sportsfield is located at:

5th Street between 47th Avenue & 46th Road, Long Island City


From Grand Central it's 3 minutes/1 stop on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.

From Queensboro it's 3 minutes/3 stops on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.
results.name: Soccer for fun!

results.description:
Bring your UAV / sUAS Drones to our regular Build and Configure get together. If you don't have one yet and are planning to buy/build soon, you are also welcome to attend.

There is plenty of space and lots of help so you can build and configure your bird(s) ready for our future Fly-Ins.

Basic tools are on hand, but bring your own specialty tools and, initially, any 'bits and pieces' you might need.  As the group grows and members come, we'll buy those 'bits and pieces' to have on hand for you..

There is a small area nearby that can be used for testing to a height of 100ft and we'll be arranging a nearby field for higher flights soon..
results.name: Join the NJ Drone User Group - Build and Config

results.description:
This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe, Please bring  $4 in cash.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP BY MIDNIGHT BEFORE THE GAME!

• RSVPs close by 9:45AM (2 hours before the start time)


• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.


Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Brooklyn Soccer Club activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Brooklyn Soccer Club Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Brooklyn Soccer Club or activities.
results.how_to_find_us: Coach Moe will be wearing a neon yellow pinnie.
results.name: PICK UP GAME 90 mins SUN 11:45 AM Cadman Plaza

results.description:
Why did Cato the elder conclude all of his speeches with, "Carthage must be destroyed"? We'll discuss the multiple conflicting spheres of influence and who was a threat to whom in the Mediterranean during the early part of Rome's ascendancy.

Suggested reading:  The Fall of Carthage (Adrian Goldsworthy);  Carthage Must be Destroyed: The Rise and Fall of an Ancient Civilization (Richard  Miles)

Please note:  The topic for the 25th has been slimmed down to a more manageable size. We'll pick up the Scipionic circle, 3rd Punic War, Macedonian Wars, Seleucid War and 2nd century Rome in the next meeting.
results.name: Wars - Carthage, Pyrrhic War and 1st and 2nd Punic War

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 12pm-3pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.
results.how_to_find_us: 39th street between 7th & 8th ave (closer to 8th ave). Take elevator to 14th floor and look on the white board for "Steve".
results.name: Improv NOW! - Sunday Drop-In Improv Class 12-3pm ($10)

group.name: Improv NOW! - NYC Weekly Improv Classes

results.description:
If you've never explored DNA before, not sure what's involved this afternoon event may be of interest. DNA is now a fast growing area of interest to identify DNA country of origins, expand one's family tree, find new family members, resolve adoption mysteries - and grant you in the neighborhood of 600 genetic cousins!

The Genealogy Event newly branded as #GENGEN and for the DNA focus (GENetics over GENerations) will return this fall for an afternoon session focused on DNA: types of tests available, how to interpret results after testing via the Family Tree DNA portal, using the Genealogical Proof Standard to validate research conclusions and finish up with several success stories.

All 3 tests: Y-DNA, mitochondrial and atDNA (autosomal) will be on sale at event.

For those not familiar with the Scandinavia House it is centrally located at 38th and Park, just a few minutes from Grand Central, the NYPL, the Morgan Library to name a few. It has a restaurant on-site and is one block away from a Starbucks, several restaurants and coffee shops.


Tickets: http://gengen.ticketleap.com/gengen/details

Early bird offers through to Sun Sept 13, 5PM
results.name: GENGEN (GENetics over GENerations) *DNA Focus*

results.description:
After 4 years in LA & Chicago and a sold out run in NYC, the hit comedy Women Are Crazy Because Men Are A**holes returns, shining its harsh and hilarious spotlight on relationships in the modern world. Perfect show for singles...both women & men!

You will also meet up to 40 other members at our Pre-Mingle. 

GET TICKETS HERE - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/menwomen/

We will meet for the pre-mingle (12pm) at a local bar/pub near the theater, where we will hand out the show tickets. 

The pre-mingle location will be sent to the email address used to purchase ticket, closer to event date. Food and drink will be available for purchase at pre-mingle. This event is not meant to be a gender balanced or age specific. All are welcome.

Package for the tickets & pre-mingle - $49.75 to $59.75 (depending upon how early you purchase your ticket). Must Prepay to attend. An RSVP alone will not hold your spot. 

Get your tickets ASAP at this link - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/menwomen/

https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=136&v=_3wOfj3Rbuk

Story -

Hit comedy Women Are Crazy Because Men Are A**holes shines a harsh and hilarious spotlight on relationships in the modern world. The play, from writer-director Brad Gottfred, centers around the single Nicole, who's finally meeting her new crush, Dylan, after a two-month internet courtship. The two get together along with several other couples at a celebratory brunch that quickly devolves into a series of sexual misadventures among all parties involved.

results.description:
Smashing Myths about Raw Food Diets

Sunday, October 25, 2015    12 pm to 5 pm


Raw Food Potluck at 12 pm, workshop begins at 1 pm.

Investment in your health: $99 in advance, $120 at the door

This class will cover in depth:

• Are enzymes as important as they say?


• How important is food combining?


• Does all fructose turn to fat in the liver?


• The human micro biome and raw foods


• Can you eat low fruit, low fat, all raw?


• Are mono meals the healthiest?


• Is fruit acidic?


• Does everyone need iodine tablets?


• Does raw kale damage the thyroid?


• Does fasting cause metabolic damage?


• Is social media the best source of info?


• And more!!


• Note Packet Included!!

Easy to follow powerpoint slide show

Drs. Karin and Rick Dina, D.C. have been thriving on a raw vegan diet since 1987 and 1990 respectively. They combine their personal, clinical, and research experience into a highly effective, scientifically valid approach to nutrition for their patients and students in the real world. They are the authors of The Raw Food Nutrition Handbook and the highly acclaimed Science of Raw Food Nutrition curriculum taught to hundreds of students from all over the world, and maintain an international lab testing and nutrition consulting practice.

Seating Is Limited

To register, please call[masked] or email Karen at [masked]     For additional class details, visit:


www.RawFoodEducation.com

results.description:
Join us for a day of open source work in JavaScript! 

Beverages and snacks will be provided by Viacom. 

Did you know you can make meaningful contributions to JavaScript code powering thousands of websites, and running in millions of browsers? 

You can improve your JavaScript coding, technical writing and collaboration skills, and also expand your professional network, and help advance the art of software engineering all in one fun way: contribute to JavaScript open source! It looks good on your resume, teaches you how to be thorough and work within teams, and gives you inside access to some of the coolest projects being built.



FORMAT

This is a workshop for people who are familiar with front-end development or JavaScript.  And it’s ok if you’ve never contributed to open source. We will try to have activities for every skill level, not to mention mentors to help you get unstuck.


EXAMPLE TASKS

• Improving documentation

• Writing tutorials/guides

• Collecting resources

• Adding features

• Adding tests

• Fixing bugs

• Helping other people do all of these things


PREREQUISITES

• Setup a GitHub account: https://github.com/join

• Learn how to submit a pull request: https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request/


BRING

• Your laptop with charger

AGENDA (PLEASE ARRIVE ON TIME!)

• 12:00-12:30 – intro to OSS & share available projects & tickets

• 12:30-12:45 – break into teams

• 12:45-4:30 – learning & hacking

• 4:30-5:00 – show and tell


LEAD FACILITATOR

Aidan Feldman, Software Engineer at 18F


MENTORS

• Jason Laster (Marionette.js core)

• Justin Ridgewell (Backbone, Underscore, lodash lead contributor)

• Gina Chiodo (a top 1% Javascript contributor)


• Henry Zhu (React, Angular, Gulp, and more...)


• Julian Simioni (Mapzen Pelias open source team) 

• Josh Bedo

• Alexander Fraczak

FAQs

Q: Is there any prep work that I need to do ahead of time?

A: Yes, please create a GitHub account and learn how to do a pull request.

Q: What if I get stuck?

You will be pairing up, and there will be awesome mentors around!

Q: Why should I spend my weekend coding?

Meet cool people. Learn from top devs. Maybe you can even earn a limited-edition tee from Hacktoberfest.


Interested in having people contribute to your open source project? Would you like to mentor? Want to ask a question? Have a suggestion for how we could make this workshop better? Drop us a line at [masked], and/or check out our planning document.


ABOUT THE HOST / SPONSOR

Viacom is providing space, snacks and beverages for the event. 

From hits like SpongeBob SquarePants and the MTV Video Music Awards, to the BET Honors, The Daily Show and blockbuster films like Forrest Gump and The Godfather and Indiana Jones series, Viacom's media networks don't just reflect popular culture, they shape it. With over 160 channels and more than 400 interactive properties across the globe, Viacom is a leading creator of entertainment programming and content, connecting its iconic brands with audiences everywhere through television, movies, music, animation, websites, games, videos, virtual worlds and consumer products

= = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = =

NY JavaScript expects all speakers and attendees to follow the JSConf Code of Conduct.

Due to limited seating, RSVPs for this event is $3. There are no refunds or transfers. Proceeds go to ScriptEd, a charity to increase code literacy among NYC youth at under-resourced schools.

If you would like to sponsor or speak at one of our events, please email us at [masked].
results.name: First-Time Open Source Contributor Workshop [JavaScript-Focused­]

results.description:
A one day (three-hour) workshop for writers who want to or are currently working on a novel. This workshop examines story structure in three contemporary YA novels. Please read these three novels before the workshop. If you don't read the books you will still come away with some guidelines for developing your YA novel. Read the books and the experience will be much richer.

"Speak" by Laurie Halse Anderson
"Brooklyn Burning" by Steve Brezenoff
"If I Stay" by Gayle Forman

We will examine story structure, characters and conceits. You will then have an opportunity to evaluate or create the preliminary structure or outline of your own novel. I will also introduce an upcoming 12 week series "Write Your YA Novel in 12 weeks".
results.name: Workshop: Story Structure in the YA Novel

results.description:
A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.
results.name: The Artist's Way

results.description: Hangout and socialize! Let's talk about current subjects, have intellectual discussions and have some brunch. Here we can also discuss possible humanistic efforts we can engage in as a group.
results.name: Brunch at Gallery Bar

results.description:
Photographer & Model Photoshoot Society Presents:

"Sexy Halloween Shoot with Lily Marie & Jenny - Oct. 25"

We are back with our last Halloween shoot of the month and we have the beautiful Lily Marie and Jenny back for some sexy Halloween fun. We all know Lily brings her all to or shoots and is always a pleasure to have join us. Jenny is also known to most of us and she just loves Halloween so we are expecting some surprises from her.

About the Shoot:

For this Halloween shoot we are going to experiment with some dramatic lighting and our smoke machine for some cool Halloween effect. We'll shoot for some sexy Halloween, pinup styles but also for some darker, horror styled looks.

or new members: Please take the time to read the info below about how the Meetup is organized and how the shooting parameters are setup.

Cost: $80

(Cash preferred, Credit Cards/Paypal ok with $5 added for surcharge)

(Non-Commercial Release provided onsite or PDF version to email registered upon check-in.)

Models:

Lily Marie: MM#699957 

(Photo Credits: NandoPro)

(Photo sent by model for promotional purposes. All photo rights their respective owners.)


Jenny Barr: Instagram 

(PhotoCredit: NandoPro)

One-on-Ones: The models will be available for half hour one on one shoots after the Meetup. If you want to pre-book time before the shoot, send me a message.

NEW Shared One-on-Ones: We are also implementing a system that has been working for the past few Meetups. It's the sharing of a half hour one on one with a fellow photographer. It can be shared together for the whole half hour or 15 minutes each photographer. 

____________________________________________________________________

About the Studio:

The studios is a beautiful 3,000 sq. ft., climate controlled,  fully functional studio. (Professional in-house lights, props, various seamless backdrops, actual commercial photography sets, kitchen, waiting room, meeting/presentation room, the works!) It's conveniently located to major highways and a 20-30 minute public transportation ride to and from NY.

About The Meetup Format:

We will keep the group small although we have the space to accommodate a big group. This keeps things from feeling rushed and overwhelming. Each photographer will have a set amount of time per look. This will allow you to  shoot as you would in an actual client shoot and not have to worry about the number of shots you are taking. (This proved to be ideal in our previous shoots as far as being able to get "the shot" and enough time to do so. Think of it as a mini one-on-one time with the model.) During the shoot we may opt to give a theme a direction to shoot for. As it would be for an actual client. (Ex: If the setup calls for a "cover shot" then it will give you a direction to aim for and to consider what equipment to use or what mood to capture.) No worries, bring what lens or lenses you have, you'll learn to use what you have for best results. We strive to bring forth real world conditions and parameters so there is a methodology to a setup or theme.

Check-in Procedure and Disclaimers:

Check-in - When you arrive, there will be a quick check-in. This will mostly be so you can read and adhere to the studio/group shoot guidelines and make payment for the shoot before we start. This will also let us send you the release forms in PDF format if we don't have physical copies available.

Releases - We will have one non-commercial release signed by the model through the studio only. (No additional releases will be signed.) If you need a commercial release signed, you can make arrangements with the model directly. Additional compensation for this is between the model and photographer.

Right to Refuse - We have the right to refuse a member's RSVP to the Meetup. It's a small community and models keep detailed info on photographers also. If we feel there is justifiable reason to refuse a RSVP, we will exercise that right.

Signups - Please signup when you know you will attend. If the signup passes the point to book another model and then we get no shows it's not fair to your fellow photographers who would be on a waiting list. It also puts the organizers in a tough spot, financially after booking an additional model to compensate for a bigger group. So, at the very least give us 3 days notice that you will not be able to attend or in case of no show, we will have to remove you from the group. When emergencies come up past the 3 days notice, followup with an email and we can make exceptions on a case by case basis. 

Model Cancellation - If a model cancels or a last minute model change occurs, you will have the option to cancel beforehand or not attend the Meetup on the day of, if it happens upon arrival to the Meetup.

Waitlist - When you are on a wait list, please be mindful as this is also considered a RSVP of availability. So, if we add another model or someone cancels within the 3 days before the shoot, your wait list status may upgrade to a "Yes". Please be on the lookout for updates on the Meetup page as Meetup sometimes takes longer to notify of a status change.

Updates - Updates will be made on this page up to the date of the Meetup or the night before. Emails will also be sent but Meetup emails are not always reliable to be sent to a receiver right away. (I've heard of emails arriving 3 hours later if at all.)

Postponements - Weather considerations will be made the night before a shoot or on the day of and the Meetup page will be updated as well as emails sent if a postponement occurs due to inclement weather or some other emergency. Lack of minimum RSVP to hold the event will also cause postponement of the shoot. The night before we would make the call wether to postpone so be on the look out for our email and Meetup page updates.

Any questions please email me at [masked]

results.description:
Updated October 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park on weekdays and Morningside Park for weekends.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th & Manhattan Ave) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Morningside Park (110th & Manhattan Ave) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End) 
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

Damien 
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).
results.why: It's fun and you like it...
results.how_to_find_us: Look for flying discs...
results.name: Sunday Ultimate @ 12PM, Morningside Park

http://www.nybg.org/frida/fall.html

Current Prices

Weekends, Monday Holidays, and Select Peak Days

Adults: $25

Students (with valid ID): $22

Children (2–12): $10Children under 2: Free

Members: Free

DÍA DE LOS MUERTOS WEEKENDS

October 24 & 25 and October 31 & November 1


FRIDA KAHLO concludes with a celebration of the Mexican tradition known for bringing together family and friends to remember loved ones, Día de los Muertos. For two weekends in late October, join in the festivities with a procession of larger-than-life skeletons, butterflies, and La Catrina—the grande dame of this colorful holiday—hand-crafted by Lucrecia Novoa, or stroll the Conservatory Plaza with the stilt dancers of Los Zancudos de Zaachila presented by Laura Anderson Barbata. Dress the part by creating your own mask to wear or having your face painted for the occasion! Artists in residence The Villalobos Brothers close out these weekend fiestas at the Garden with performances on October 31 & November 1.


Giant Pumpkin Carving Weekend with Ray VillafaneOctober 24 & 25; 10 a.m.–6 p.m.


Watch Master Carver Ray Villafane transform giant pumpkins into a Día de los Muertos tableau. Enjoy daily Q&A sessions with his additional carvers. From October 24 through November 1, giant pumpkins supplied by the Great Pumpkin Commonwealth will once again be on display in the Garden, some weighing more than a ton!

Giant Pumpkin DisplayOctober 24–November 1; 10 a.m.–6 p.m.


Giant pumpkins from North America once again arrive at the Garden, arranged in collaboration with the Great Pumpkin Commonwealth. See how you measure up against these giants, some weighing more than a ton!

results.description:
Moderate Hike on the Palisades this Sunday 10/24. Fit beginners welcome. Giant Stairs (scrambling). Possible off-piste intense scramble option.  (Ask!)

Colors should be peaking!

Bring some snacks/lunch, at least a liter of water, flashlight/headlamp, hat/gloves/warm clothing.  Proper footwear.  There is a lot of prep info on the Pages tab if you are a beginnner.  

We'll be on the trail rougly 4 or hours, more if we take longer stops.  

No Guests.  Have a guest? Have him/her join the group and RSVP.  

-----------------------------------------

Legal Stuff.  Must Read

Hiking and scrambling are dangerous and you could get hurt of killed.  We are not professional guides and we never charge for organizing these hikes.  We may or may not know what we are doing.  

That said: if you show up for this event, it means you are taking responsibility of for your own safety and will not hold the organizers, hosts, or other members responsible for your injury or death.  Should you be injured or killed, you promise not to bring suit of any kind against the organizers/hosts/other members.  This release applies to your heirs and assigns as well.

results.description:
Come and photograph the majestic Grand Central terminal -- capture all of the details in the shadows and highlights with HDR photography! We have special permission to use tripods during this five hour workshop. We have led workshops to photograph the Grand Central terminal with tripods more than a dozen times. 

We will meet at 12:30 at GCT and shoot from 1pm until 6 pm. Some people do not have the stamina for a five hour shoot, there are seats in the food court downstairs and seats in the station master's office where you can rest, or you may leave early (just turn in your permit before leaving).

Meet outside of the station master's office, there is an area to the left of the SMO. The SMO is the customer waiting area with the glass doors on the upper level of the terminal, at the top and just to the right of the escalators on the west side of the building (near tracks 34/35 and the Transit Museum store.

You will be taking 3-10 exposures in order to capture all of the details in the shadows and highlights. Tom and I will be helping you with compositions, checking exposures, etc. For the first hour we are very hands on helping you with your camera settings, interpreting histograms, etc. 

After the first hour we will be shooting too, but will aid you with compositions, answer questions, check in on your exposures, etc. 

Experienced photographers can utilize us for as little or as much assistance as desired. for many of our participants getting the inside scoop on locations and compositions and getting access and being able to use a tripod is reason enough to come with us! We will get you up to speed because we have been there with tripods so many times we know some great compositions!

As always, you must sign sign a liability waiver for this photo tour.

Please note that all of our workshops require the participants sign a liability waiver. Download it here; then print, read and sign it. Some venues may also require a location liability waiver.

See more images here:
results.how_to_find_us: Meet outside of the station master's office, to the left of the SMO. See below
results.name: HDR (High Dynamic Range) Workshop with tripods at Grand Central

results.description:
The rise of Julius Caesar spelled the end of the Roman Republic and the rise of the West's first and most memorable empire.  What caused the Republic's decline? How did the Empire establish itself on its ruins? And what enabled Rome to grow and thrive through it all?

Come join like-minded amateur historians to revisit this fascinating episode in the history of western civilization.  Together, we will think through the legacy of the Julio-Claudian Emperors -- Caesar's successors, Augustus, Tiberius, Caligula, Claudius, and Nero -- who buried the republic and built the new regime.
results.name: The Fall of the Roman Republic and Rise of the Roman Empire

results.description:
Join us at Dennis P. McHugh Piermont Public Library on October 25th at 1 p.m. for Winter Container Gardening presented by Vivienne Dieckmann, Master Gardener with Cornell University Cooperative Extension of Rockland. This lively and informative presentation highlights valuable tips and easy techniques for growing ornamentals and miniature evergreens throughout the fall and winter. It will also demonstrate different methods of decorating the containers with branches, berries, and twigs for the holiday season. Through the use of live, winter-hardy plants and shrubs that have interesting texture and form, the winter container will provide long-lasting color through the cold, snowy months. This event is free and open to all. Registration is encouraged. Call[masked]-4595.

The Dennis P. McHugh Piermont Public Library is located at 25 Flywheel Park West in Piermont, New York. Visit us at piermontlibrary.org
results.name: Winter Container Gardening Talk at Dennis P. McHugh Piermont Public Library

results.description:
The Underdark's Deep Wastes lay beneath the Dalelands and the Moonsea. Here drow worship their Spider Queen Lolth and plot against the hated surface world, but something new has arisen... Fire giants have taken the undercity of Maerimydra... and a dark power of self-indulgence and narcissism spreads madness... Who dares enter such subterranean realms?

Although there is no cover charge for this event, because the venue is a bar/restaurant, players should factor in ordering brunch (see menu at http://www.lovecraftnyc.com plus drink specials on-site).

We're using 5th edition Dungeons & Dragons with multiple DMs running open tables. You can download the basic rules (with 4 classes, 4 races) for free at http://bit.ly/1EzS3Uq -- new/returning players welcome, pre-gen characters and everything provided but bring dice if you got 'em along with food/drink money.

UPDATE: WE STILL NEED DUNGEON MASTERS! We've lowered the initial RSVP list ahead of a waitlist to keep the table manageable, but if more people are interested in helping run games, we can take more players! Let us know!
